snippet.title: CBSE Class 10 | Geography | Industries Mineral Based Industries |
snippet.description:
In this module, you will learn about Manufacturing industries that use minerals as raw material are called mineral-based industries.
The iron and steel industry is the basic industry in which all other industries depend.
The production and per capita consumption of steel is a measure of a country’s economic development.
The main raw materials used in the iron and steel industry are iron ore, coal, and limestone.
An iron and steel plant must be located near a mining area of the required minerals and must be connected by a good transport network.
India is the ninth largest producer of crude steel and the largest producer of sponge iron in the world.
The per capita consumption of steel in India is only 32 kilograms.
There are 10 primary integrated steel plants in India.
India has many mini steel plants that produce customized alloy steel using scrap iron or sponge iron as the raw material.
China has become the world’s largest producer and consumer of steel, leaving India far behind.  
Most steel manufacturing industries are located in the Chhota Nagpur Plateau region due to:
The availability of inexpensive, high-grade raw material
Abundant cheap labor 
The main challenges faced by the iron and steel industry are:
Limited supply of expensive coking coal
Erratic power supply
The low output of labor 
Poor infrastructure
The future of the Indian iron and steel industry is bright due to India’s liberalization policy and foreign direct investment in the industry. 
Aluminium is a lightweight, corrosion-resistant metal with excellent malleability and ductility. 
Aluminum is a good conductor of heat and electricity and can be alloyed with other metals to make it stronger.
Aluminum is increasingly being used as a substitute for steel, copper, zinc, and lead in several industries.
Aluminum smelting is the second most important metallurgical industry in India.
Bauxite is the chief ore of aluminum.
Bauxite is refined to produce alumina, which is smelted to derive metallic aluminum.
India has 8 aluminium smelting plants in Orissa, West Bengal, Uttar Pradesh, Tamil Nadu, Kerala, Chhattisgarh and Maharashtra.
An assured supply of power and good transport connectivity are the main criteria for the location of aluminum smelting plants.
India’s chemical industry is the third largest in Asia and the 12th largest in the world. It contributes 3% to our national GDP.
The main inorganic chemicals produced in India include sulphuric acid, nitric acid, alkalis, soda ash and caustic soda.
Sulphuric acid is used in the production of fertilizers, plastics, synthetic fibers, adhesives, paints, and dyes. 
Soda ash is used in manufacturing soap, glass, detergents and paper.
Petrochemicals are materials derived as by-products of petroleum refining.
Petrochemicals are used to manufacture synthetic fiber, synthetic rubber, dyes and paints, fertilizers, adhesives and medicinal drugs.

snippet.title: CBSE Class 10 | Geography | Conservation of Energy |
snippet.description:
In this module, you will learn about Energy requirements are rising in all parts of India.
We are largely dependent on fuel minerals like coal, petroleum and natural gas to fulfil our energy requirements.
Minerals are non-renewable resources. Thus, the supply of coal, petroleum and natural gas is limited.
Heavy dependence on fuel minerals for energy is not a sustainable plan to meet our future energy requirements.
A sustainable path of energy development involves:
Finding renewable, non-conventional sources of energy.
Conservation of energy.
A lot of energy is wasted in our country through inefficient means of usage. 
We can conserve fuel minerals by:
Forming carpools and using public transport instead of private vehicles.
Using better, renewable fuels like biogas in place of coal for cooking purposes.   
We can conserve energy by:
Switching off all lights, fans and electrical devices when not required.
Using power saving devices.

snippet.title: CBSE Class 10 | Geography | Electricity And Non Conventional Sources of Energy |
snippet.description:
In this module, you will learn about Electricity And Non Conventional Sources of Energy, Hydroelectricity is generated by the energy of flowing water, which is a renewable resource.
Thermal electricity is generated by burning of non-renewable fuel minerals like coal, petroleum and natural gas.
India has over 310 thermal power plants.
Nuclear or atomic energy is also used to generate electricity.
India currently has six operational nuclear power plants.
Increasing prices, shortage in supply and environmental concerns against using fossil fuels can severely affect our energy security.
The answer to the problem of energy security lies in using non-conventional sources of energy.
Photovoltaic technology uses panels made of photovoltaic cells that trap solar energy and convert it into electricity.
The use of solar energy in rural India can reduce dependence on firewood and cattle dung cakes.
Wind turbines convert the energy of blowing wind into electricity.
Animal, human and farm waste produce biogas on decomposition, which is a better fuel than kerosene, cattle dunk cakes, firewood and coal.
Biogas plants that operate on animal waste are called gobar gas plants in India.
Oceanic tides are used to generate electricity called tidal energy.
The heat trapped in the depths of the earth is called geothermal energy.
Experimental projects to utilise geothermal energy have been set up at the Parvati Valley near Manikaran in Himachal Pradesh, and the Puga Valley in Ladakh.

snippet.title: CBSE Class 10 | Geography | Ferrous and Non Ferrous Minerals |
snippet.description:
In this module, you will learn about Ferrous and Non Ferrous Minerals, Ferrous minerals contain iron, while non-ferrous minerals do not contain iron.
Ferrous minerals constitute about 75% of the total production of minerals in India.
India exports substantial amounts of ferrous minerals.
The two main ores of iron are magnetite and hematite. 
Magnetite has up to 70% iron, while hematite has 50-60% iron.
Karnataka and Orissa are the main iron ore producing states in India, followed by Chhattisgarh, Goa and Jharkhand.
The major iron ore producing areas in India are: 
The Orissa-Jharkhand belt
The Durg-Bastar-Chandrapur belt
The Bellary-Chitradurga-Chikmaglur-Tumkur belt
The Maharashtra-Goa belt
High-grade hematite is mined in the Badampahar mines in Mayurbhanj and Kendujhar districts of Orissa.
The Durg-Bastar-Chandrapur belt is spread over parts of Chhattisgarh and Maharashtra.
The Bellary-Chitradurga-Chikmaglur-Tumkur belt lies in Karnataka.
The Kudermukh mines hold one of the largest deposits of iron ore in the world.
Orissa is the main manganese-producing state in India, followed by Madhya Pradesh and Karnataka.
The Maharashtra-Goa belt is spread over parts of Goa and Ratnagiri district of Maharashtra.
None-ferrous minerals are not as abundant in India as ferrous minerals.
Copper is widely used in the electrical, electronics and chemical industries.
Madhya Pradesh, Rajasthan and Jharkhand are the main copper-producing states in India.
Bauxite is the main ore of aluminium.
Orissa is the main bauxite-producing state in India followed by Gujarat, Jharkhand and Maharashtra.

snippet.title: CBSE Class 10 | Geography | Non Metallic Minerals |
snippet.description:
In this module, you will learn about Non Metallic Minerals, Mica is a non-metallic mineral composed of thin leaves or sheets joined together.
Mica is found in many colours, from transparent to black, green, tallow, brown and red.
Mica provides excellent electrical insulation with low power loss even at very high voltages.
Mica is used extensively in the electrical and electronics industries.
The main mica producing regions in India are the northern Chhota Nagpur Plateau in Jharkhand, Ajmer in Rajasthan and Nellore in Andhra Pradesh.
The Koderma, Gaya and Hazaribagh belt in Jharkhand is the largest producer of mica in India.
Limestone is a form of sedimentary rock composed almost entirely of calcium carbonate.
Limestone is mainly used in smelting iron ore and manufacturing of cement.
Andhra Pradesh is the main limestone-producing state in India, followed by Madhya Pradesh, Rajasthan, Gujarat, Tamil Nadu and others.
Workers engaged in mining face serious risks to their health and life.
Indiscriminate mining leads to extensive deforestation.
Dumping of mining waste results in soil and land degradation, and the pollution of air and fresh water bodies.
We need stricter laws and the implementation of personal and environmental safety regulations to keep mining a safe activity.
Usable minerals are only about 1 percent of the earth’s crust.
Minerals are limited and non-renewable resources.
Continuous mining starts yielding poor quality ores at much higher cost.
We need to conserve our mineral resources.
Recycling and reusing material and finding suitable substitutes of minerals can help us conserve our mineral resources.

snippet.title: CBSE Class 10 | Geography | Types and Occurrence of Minerals |
snippet.description:
In this module, you will learn about Types and Occurrence of Minerals, Minerals are naturally occurring homogeneous substances with a definite internal structure.
Some minerals are essential for our body.
A rock may contain one or several types of minerals.
A geographer studies the distribution and economic importance of a mineral.
A geologist studies the formation, age and composition of minerals.
The properties of a mineral depend on its constitution, elements and conditions of formation.
Minerals can be classified as:
Metallic minerals
Ferrous minerals
Non-ferrous minerals
Precious metals
Non-metallic minerals
Energy or fuel minerals
Minerals occur in the earth’s crust as:
Veins and lodes in igneous and metamorphic rocks
Beds or layers in sedimentary rocks
Alluvial or placer deposits on valley floors
Residual mass after weathering of surrounding rocks
Ocean water and the ocean floor are also rich in mineral deposits.
India has rich mineral resources in some parts of its territory.
To be an ore, a mineral should:
Be abundantly available
Offer sufficient concentration of an element
Have a commercially viable process of extraction
The places from where mineral ores are extracted are called mines.
All the mineral reserves in India are owned by the government.
In Meghalaya, families lay claim to coal deposits, and mine coal by digging long narrow tunnels in the ground. This practice is called rat hole mining.

snippet.title: CBSE Class 10 | Geography | Development and Planning of Resources |
snippet.description:
In this module, you will learn about Development and Planning of Resource, Sustainable development means using resources wisely without damaging the environment and keeping in mind the need of future generations.
Indiscriminate use of resources leads to:
A rapid depletion of resources.
An economic divide in the society.
Environmental and ecological problems like pollution, land degradation, global warming and ozone layer depletion. 
The first Earth Summit was held in 1992 at Rio de Janeiro in Brazil, where leaders from over 100 countries:
Signed the Declaration on Global Climatic Change and Biological Diversity.
Approved the global forest principles.
Adopted Agenda 21.
Agenda 21 aims to:
Prevent damage to the environment.
Fight poverty and disease.
Encourage governments to form their own Agenda 21 based on local issues.
Resources in a country are not distributed uniformly across all its regions.
The mere presence of resources is not enough for the development of a region.
Resource planning involves finding appropriate technology, skilled human resources, setting up of suitable institutions and equitable distribution of available resources for sustained economic development.
Resource planning involves:
Identifying and estimating available resources through surveying and mapping.
Evolving technology, skilled personnel and institutions to implement resource development plans.
Continuously monitoring and guiding resource development plans to match the overall national development goals.
Irresponsible and over-use of resources can lead to several social, economic and environmental problems.
We must plan for the future and start conserving our resources at all levels.

snippet.title: CBSE Class 10 | Geography | Land Resources |
snippet.description:
In this module, you will learn about Land Resources, India is the 7th largest country in the world with a geographical area of about 3.28 million sq. km.
Out of the total land area of India:
43% is plain
30% is mountains
27% is plateau region
Depending on their use, our land resources can be classified as forests, net sown area, fallow land, other uncultivated land and land not available for cultivation.
Fallow lands can be further divided into current fallow and other than current fallow. 
Uncultivated land other than fallow land is divided into permanent pastures, land under miscellaneous tree crops and land left uncultivated for more than five years.
Land not available for cultivation is either barren wasteland or land used for non-agricultural purposes. 
The area under forests is way below the required 33% as planned in the National Forest Policy.
The area under permanent pastures and grazing grounds is decreasing.
Continuous and indiscriminate use of land resources results in land degradation.
Human activity has contributed to and increased the pace of natural land degradation.
Deforestation removes the green cover required to prevent soil erosion.
Overgrazing by cattle turns permanent pastures into barren land. 
Indiscriminate deforestation and excavation carried out as part of mining activity also causes land degradation.
Disposal of solid and liquid waste by industries on surrounding land or water bodies has also become a major cause of land degradation and water pollution.
Some steps for land conservation are:
Afforestation
Controlled grazing and mining activity
Stabilisation of sand dunes.
Proper disposal of industrial effluents after treatment
Continuous monitoring of soil conditions

snippet.title: CBSE Class 10 | Geography | Soil As a Resource |
snippet.description:
In this module, you will learn about Soil As a Resource, Soil is formed over millions of years by weathering of rock by natural agents like variation in temperature, wind, glaciers and running water.
Soil is a natural, abiotic, renewable resource.
Soil is an essential resource that supports majority of plant and animal life on the Earth.
Usually soil refers to the thin layer of the top soil or fine upper layer of soil in a region.
Alluvial soils are found in plains of north India, coastal plains and deltas of the rivers Godavari, Mahanadi, Krishna and Kaveri.
New alluvial soils (Khadar) found in Gangetic plains have a fine texture and small particles. 
Old alluvial soils (Bangar) found near the river valleys are coarser and contain more pieces of rocks called Kanker.
The fertile alluvial soils are ideal for growing sugarcane, wheat, rice, pulses and vegetable crops.
Black soil is found in the Deccan plateau region spread over Maharashtra, Saurashtra, Malwa, Madhya Pradesh and Chhattisgarh.
Black soil is ideally suited for cultivation of cotton.
Red and yellow soils are found in southern and eastern parts of Deccan plateau, southern Gangetic plains, along the Western Ghats and some parts of Orissa and Chhattisgarh.
Red and yellow soils are good for cultivating various types of grams, groundnuts and castor seeds.
Laterite soils are found in Kerala, Karnataka, Madhya Pradesh, Tamil Nadu and parts of Orissa and Assam.
Laterite soil is good for cultivation of tea, coffee and cashew nuts.
Arid soil is found in Rajasthan and parts of Gujarat that receive very little rainfall.
Arid soil is being used for cultivation of bajra and wheat crops in some places of western Rajasthan where irrigation facility is available.
Forest soils are found in the mountainous regions of the Himalayas from Kashmir to Arunachal Pradesh.
Wheat, rice, sugarcane, and oil seeds are cultivated in forest soils of many parts in Jammu and Kashmir and Arunachal Pradesh.

snippet.title: CBSE Class 10 | Geography | Soil Erosion and Conservation |
snippet.description:
In this module, you will learn about Soil Erosion and Conservation, The loss of soil cover due to natural agents like wind and running water is called soil erosion.
The roots of plants and trees keep the soil moist and hold the soil particles together.
Humans destroy vegetation cover by: 
Deforestation
Overgrazing 
Mining activities
Without vegetation cover, soil becomes dry and loose and gets easily eroded.
Defective farming methods, like ploughing up and down a slope, increase the rate of soil erosion.
The formation of deep channels in clay soils by running water is called gully erosion. 
The washing away of the entire sheet of top soil in a region by water is called sheet erosion.
Terrace farming and ploughing land along contour lines reduce the speed of water flowing down the slope and help in soil conservation.
In strip cropping, strips of grass standing between crops reduce the force of wind and thus prevent soil erosion.
Shelter belts of trees help in soil conservation by breaking the force of wind and stabilising sand dunes near farmlands.

snippet.title: CBSE Class 10 | Geography | Types of Resources |
snippet.description:
In this module, you will learn about The things available in our environment that can be used to satisfy a requirement are called resources.
Things available in our environment become resources only when human beings find a way to transform them into a useful form.
For a thing to become a resource:
Suitable technology must exist to transform it into some useful form.
Its use must be financially viable and culturally acceptable.
Resources can be classified based on their origin, exhaustibility, ownership and status of development.
All resources that come from living things, like forests, land and sea animals, insects and human beings, are called biotic resources.
Resources in the form of non-living things, like rocks, minerals and metals, are called abiotic resources.
Resources like solar and wind energy, reversible chemical reactions and physical power, which can be regenerated once used, are called renewable resources.
Fossil fuels like coal, natural oil and gas and minerals, which are lost forever once used, are examples of non-renewable resources.
Resources like private houses, shops, farms and plantations, are owned by individual persons, and are called individual resources.
Resources like public parks, places of worship, schools and hospitals are open to all members of a community. These are examples of community-owned resources.
All biotic, abiotic, individual or community owned resources ultimately belong to the country, and are called national resources.
Resources found on land and the vast stretches of oceans, which are not owned by any particular nation, are called international resources.
Resources like mines, where minerals have already been discovered and production is on to utilise their full capacity, are called developed resources.
Resources that are known to exist, but are not being fully utilised, are called potential resources.
Resources that cannot be used due to the unavailability of suitable technology, but may be used in the future, are called stock.
Resources that can be used today, but are preserved to meet future requirements, are called reserves.

snippet.title: CBSE Class 10 | Geography | Multi Purpose River Projects |
snippet.description:
In this module, you will learn about Multi Purpose River Projects, People have always felt the need to store river water in the rainy season for use in the dry season.
People in ancient India built many hydraulic structures like dams, artificial lakes, tanks and canals to store or divert water for irrigation. 
A dam is a structure that forms a barrier across a river to regulate the flow of water.
We have built many large dams across major rivers in India.
The primary purpose of dams has always been to provide water for irrigation.
Modern dams are also used to generate electricity, and to supply water to industries and households.
Dams are also used to control flooding by regulating the flow of water.
The reservoirs created behind several dams are used for breeding fish.
Dams can also be used to divert water into existing smaller streams to promote inland navigation.
Several dams are popular tourist attractions and recreation spots.
Dams are called multi-purpose river projects due to the many ways that they offer to manage our water resources.
A dam creates an enormous reservoir of water that submerges vast stretches of the surrounding area.
Major benefits of large multi-purpose projects go to big landowners, while the local, poor, landless people have little to gain.
Better irrigation facilities are leading to over-irrigation and an increase in soil salinity.
Dams blocks upstream migration of fish for breeding, putting several species in danger.
The sudden release of large quantities of water from a dam results in large-scale flooding in plain areas.
Large dams obstruct the free flow of river water, resulting in disputes over water sharing between different states. 
Environmentalists associate large dams with causing earthquakes, spread of water-borne diseases and degradation of soil.
Most of the multi-purpose river projects in India so far have not met their desired objectives.

snippet.title: CBSE Class 10 | Geography | Water Resources Rainwater Harvesting |
snippet.description:
In this module, you will learn about Rainwater Harvesting, Rain water feeds our rivers and also seeps into the ground to recharge our underground water resources.
Rain water is available to us only for a few months in a year.
The process of collecting rain water during the wet season, to meet our fresh water requirements in the dry season, is called rainwater harvesting.
In Himachal Pradesh and Jammu, rainwater is harvested using diversion channels, called kuls or guls.
Water flowing through kuls is collected in reservoir tanks in the villages and used for irrigation as and when required.
Farmers in Bengal traditionally used inundation channels cut through river embankments at times of floods to irrigate their fields.
In the semi-arid regions of Rajasthan, earthen check dams, called johads, are used to collect rain water that percolates into the ground and raises the level of groundwater.
In some areas of Rajasthan, earthen embankments, called khadin, are built around farms to collect rainwater. This saturates the soil for cultivation.
One of the most widely used methods of collecting rain water is rooftop rainwater harvesting.
In a rooftop rainwater harvesting system, rain water falling on the roof is collected and then filtered before being stored in tanks for immediate use. Excess water is diverted to wells to recharge groundwater.
In many parts of Rajasthan, rain water collected through rooftop harvesting is collected in large underground reservoirs, called tankas.
Almost all households in Shillong in Meghalaya use rooftop rainwater harvesting to meet almost 20 percent of their total requirement of water.
Each of the 200 households in Gendathur, Karnataka, that adopted rooftop rainwater harvesting can collect 50,000 litres of rain water every year for its use.
In bamboo drip irrigation, shallow channels are made from split bamboos, which are used to divert water from rain-fed springs to the farmers. Channel sections are used in the farm to water the plants.

snippet.title: CBSE Class 10 | Geography | WATER SCARCITY |
snippet.description:
In this module, you will learn about WATER SCARCITY,  In this module you learn about the causes of water scarcity and the need for water conservation and management. What is water scarcity. The unavailability of sufficient clean water to meet personal, domestic and industrial requirements in an area is called water scarcity. We usually associate the problem of water scarcity with dry, hot regions like desserts that receives scanty rainfall and have very few celsus of clean surface water. Here is a map that shows projected water scarcity in the world by the year two thousand twenty five As you can see water scarcity is said to become a serious problem in the whole of India. Not all regions that face water scarcity have poor water resources. What leads to water scarcity in regions that have abundant water resources. An increase in demand, unequal access to water, overexploitation and contamination of existing water resources are the main factors that lead to water scarcity in regions with abundant water resources. Let us study these factors in detail. This brings us to the question what are the main causes of water scarcity? India has a second highest population in the world which is still increasing fast. An increase in population means a greater demand for fresh water for personal and domestic use. To feed the increasing population more and more land is brought under cultivation. 
This also increases the demand for water for irrigation purposes. Six independence India has seen a major industrial revolution, rapid industrialisation exerts greater demand on water resources. Since industries use a huge quantity of water for production and cleaning. Over seventy percent of India's population still lives in villages. However people living in cities have better access to water than people living in most villages. This unequal access to water resources also leads to water scarcity. Groundwater is an important freshwater resource. However in order to increase their produce most farmers today use private tube-wells to irrigate their fields. This over exploitation of underground water is leading to falling water table and water scarcity. Similarly the use of bore-wells by modern housing societies to provide water to their residents is also over-exploitation of underground water resources. Fresh water resources like rivers and lakes are often treated as dumping round for domestic use and industrial waste. This pollutes the fresh water and makes it unfit for our use. Such contamination of fresh water also contributes to water scarcity. The use of chemical fertilisers and pesticides in modern agriculture leads to pollution of fresh surface water and groundwater.

snippet.title: CBSE Class 10 | Geography | Water Resources Water Sources |
snippet.description:
In this module, you will learn about Water Resources Water Sources, Nearly 70% of the Earth is covered by water.
Water is a renewable resource that keeps moving in a hydrological cycle.
Water is essential for drinking, cooking, cleaning, washing, cultivation, industries and economic growth.
Industries require lots of water for production, cleaning and disposing waste. 
Of the total water available on the earth:
Around 97% lies in the seas and oceans.
Only 2.5% exists as fresh water.
Of the fresh water available on earth:
 Nearly 70% is locked in ice and glaciers.
Just under 30% is in the form of groundwater.
Only around 0.3% is in rivers, lakes and ponds.
A tiny fraction occurs in a form fit for human and industrial consumption.
India receives around 4% of the total rainfall in the world.
India is ranked 133rd in the world in terms of water availability per person per year.
Water scarcity is posing an alarming threat in most parts of the world, including India.

snippet.title: CBSE Class 10 | Geography | Agriculture | Cropping seasons in India |
snippet.description:
CBSE Class 10 | Geography | Agriculture | Cropping seasons in India |

In this module, you will learn about cropping seasons in India. Agriculture in India follows three distinct cropping seasons:
Rabi
Kharif
Zaid
Rabi crops are sown from October to December and harvested from April to June.
Important rabi crops are wheat, mustard, barley, grams and peas.
The important areas for rabi are Punjab, Haryana, Uttar Pradesh, Uttaranchal, Himachal Pradesh, and Jammu and Kashmir.
Kharif crops are sown in July-August with the onset of monsoons and harvested in September-October.
Important kharif crops are rice, maize, jowar, bajra, arhar (tur), moong, urad, cotton, jute, groundnut and soybean.
The main rice-producing states in India are Assam, West Bengal, Orissa, Andhra Pradesh, Tamil Nadu, Kerala, Maharashtra, Uttar Pradesh and Bihar.
The summer months between the harvesting of rabi and the sowing of kharif are called the zaid season.
Important crops grown in zaid are watermelon, muskmelon, cucumber, summer vegetables and fodder crops.

snippet.title: CBSE Class 10 | Geography | Agriculture | Major Crops |
snippet.description:
In this module, you will learn about Rice is a kharif crop that requires high temperature and humidity, and more than 100 cm of rainfall for proper growth.
Wheat is a rabi crop that requires cool weather for growth and warm weather for ripening, with 50 to 75 cm of rainfall. Maize is majorly a kharif crop that grows well in old alluvial soils at moderate temperature from 21 to 27 degrees Centigrade. Food grains like jowar, bajra and ragi are together called coarse grains or millets. Jowar is a rain-fed crop that requires little or no irrigation. Bajra grows well in shallow black soils and the sandy soils of Rajasthan. Ragi grows well in almost all types of soils like red, black, sandy or loamy soil. Pulses grow well in dry weather conditions. The nitrogen-fixing nodules in their roots help restore soil fertility. Sugarcane grows on many different kinds of soils and requires a hot, humid climate with 75 to 100 cm of rainfall. Groundnut is a kharif crop and accounts for about 50% of the total oilseeds produced in India. Linseed and mustard are rabi crops. Castor seeds are grown in both the rabi and kharif seasons. Sesame is a rabi crop in southern India and a kharif crop in northern India. Tea grows in deep, fertile, well-drained soil, and requires a warm and humid climate with frequent showers for continuous growth. The Arabica variety of coffee grown in India is appreciated the world over for its superior quality. India ranks first in the production of fruits and vegetables in the world. Rubber trees grow well in regions with hot and humid climate, and over 200 cm of rainfall every yea Cotton is a kharif crop and requires high temperature and light rainfall or irrigation for proper growth. Jute grows well on fertile well-drained soils and requires high temperature for proper growth
.

snippet.description:

Fragmentation of land holdings by successive inheritance, primitive methods of farming
Dependence on monsoon and natural fertility of soil, exploitation by local money lenders and middlemen, Lack of insurance against natural calamities, The technological and institutional changes initiated in India to improve the condition of farmers include: 
Land reforms, Abolition of zamindari, Consolidation of land holdings

Providing high yielding varieties of seeds and fertilisers to farmers., Developing large-scale irrigation facilities to allow farmers to grow two crops in a year., Continued expansion of farming areas.

Verghese Kurien is credited with architecting Operation Flood -- the largest dairy development programme in the world.

Providing marketing support by announcing the procurement, remunerative and minimum support prices of all the major crops in India. personal benefit schemes like Kisan Credit Card (KCC) and Personal Accident Insurance Scheme (PAIS).

snippet.title: CBSE Class 10 | Geography | Agriculture | Types of Farming |
snippet.description:
In this module, you will learn about Types of Farming, Agriculture has been the foundation of the Indian economy, providing occupation to nearly 67% of our population.
Raw material from agriculture also supports a number of industries like cotton textiles, food processing and handicrafts. Primitive subsistence farming:
Involves cultivating food crops in small fields essentially to sustain the farmer’s family. Depends entirely on local soil and environment conditions and monsoons. Involves hard manual labour. Is slash-and-burn agriculture. Allows the soil to regain its fertility naturally.
Gives very poor yield and leads to a large-scale destruction of forests Besides India, slash-and-burn or shifting cultivation is practiced in many parts of the world and known by different names. In India, the most popular name for such shifting cultivation is Jhumming, by which it is known in many of our north-eastern states. Intensive subsistence farming:: Is practised in densely populated areas of India
Aims to get maximum yield from the available land through extensive irrigation and use of large quantities of chemical fertilisers. Repeated division of land amongst successive generations of farmers decreases individual land holding, further encouraging farmers to use all available means to increase yield. Commercial farming: Involves the cultivation of a crop in large quantities for the purpose of selling it in the market Uses high yielding seeds, chemical fertilisers and pesticides Plantations are also forms of commercial farming. Cultivation of a crop can be classified as commercial or subsistence farming depending on the area it is grown in.

snippet.title: CBSE Class 10 | Geography | Conservation of Forest & Wildlife in India |
snippet.description:
In this module, you will learn about Conservation of plants and animals ensures the quality of air, water and soil on which we depend for our survival.
Conservation of plants species maintains their genetic diversity that is extremely beneficial for our agricultural produce.
Conservation of animal species is important for their breeding and maintenance of food chains.
The salient features of the Indian Wildlife (Protection) Act, 1972, include:
Provisions for habitat protection
Publishing a list of protected species
Provisions against hunting and poaching
Restrictions on trade in wildlife 
Setting up of national parks and sanctuaries in different parts of the country
Announcing conservation projects for some specific endangered animals
Conservation efforts in India are expanding their scope to include even insects and plants in the list of protected species.
The Wildlife Act of 1980 and 1986 included hundreds of species of butterflies, moths, beetles and one species of dragonfly in the list of protected species.
Six species of plants were included in the list of protected species in 1991.
Project Tiger, launched in 1973, is dedicated to protect and conserve the Royal Bengal Tiger.
India and Nepal are home to about two-thirds of the tiger population in the world.
The tiger population in India decreased from 55,000 to 1,827 from 1900 to 1973.
The results of Project Tiger have been mixed.
Some of the main tiger reserves are the Jim Corbett National Park in Uttarakhand, the Sunderbans National Park in West Bengal, the Bandhavgarh National Park in Madhya Pradesh, the Sariska Wildlife Sanctuary in Rajasthan, the Manas Tiger Reserve in Assam and the Periyar Tiger Reserve in Kerala.

snippet.title: CBSE Class 10 | Geography | Agriculture | Factors Responsible for Depletion of Flora & Fauna |
snippet.description:
In this module, you will learn about The Asiatic Cheetah became extinct in India in 1952.
The Himalayan Yew is an endangered medicinal plant found in Himachal Pradesh and Arunachal Pradesh that yields a substance used to treat several types of cancer.
The main reason for the depletion of fauna is excessive hunting and poaching.
The destruction of natural habitats has resulted in the depletion of wildlife.
Over-exploitation of forest resources has resulted in the depletion of flora.
In colonial India, vast stretches of natural forests were destroyed for the expansion of railways, agriculture, commercial farming and mining.
Colonial practices continued even after independence.
Poor cultivation methods like slash and burn agriculture or Jhuming have also lead to deforestation.
Large infrastructure projects, like multi-purpose dams, have also resulted in massive deforestation.
Mining also contributes to deforestation.
Overgrazing by cattle herds leads to large-scale destruction of pastures and natural forests.
Enrichment plantation is the practice of replacing different species of trees in an area by a single commercially valuable species. 
Teak plantations have damaged the natural forests in south India, while Chir Pine plantations in Himalayas have greatly reduced the natural oak and rhododendron forests.
Environmental pollution and forest fires lead to depletion of both flora and fauna.
Hunting and poaching, habitat destruction, deforestation, over-exploitation, enrichment plantations, environmental pollution and forest fires are factors responsible for the decrease in India’s biodiversity. 
However, the responsibility for the protection and conservation of the environment is not shared by the people in proportion with the resources they consume.
Depletion in flora and fauna has considerable impact on people, who are directly dependent on forests for resources and livelihood.
Women have to walk long distances to collect food and firewood, while their children and household get neglected.
Natural calamities like droughts and floods are also a result of environmental degradation, and the poorest are hit the hardest. 
India’s flora and fauna are under a severe threat, and require immediate measures of conservation.

snippet.title: CBSE Class 10 | Geography | Agriculture | Flora & Fauna in India |
snippet.description:
In this module, you will learn about We share the earth with millions of species of plants and animals.
The plants and animals maintain the quality of our planet’s air, water and soil, which are essential for the survival of humans.
Forests are the primary producers on which all the species of animals depend directly or indirectly.
The variety of living things found in a region, country or the entire earth is called its biological diversity or biodiversity.
The different species of plants and trees are collectively called flora.
The different species of animals are collectively called fauna.
India is home to around 1.6 million or nearly 8% of the total species of flora and fauna found in the world.
India is home to around 47,000 species of flora and over 81,000 species of fauna.
Over-exploitation and insensitivity towards our environment has led to large-scale degradation of biodiversity in India.
As per IUCN guidelines, species of flora and fauna can be classified as normal, extinct, endangered, vulnerable, rare or endemic.
Plants and animals whose population is sufficient for the survival of their species are called normal species.
Species that cannot be found after a prolonged search in their area of habitation are called extinct species.
Species that are facing the danger of extinction if the factors responsible for their decline are not checked are called endangered species.
Species that are likely to become endangered due to decreasing population, unless conserved, are called vulnerable species.
Species with a small population that are likely to become vulnerable or endangered without conservation efforts are called rare species.
Species found only in a particular region due to isolation by natural or geographical barriers are called endemic species.

snippet.title: CBSE Class 10 | Geography | Community Participation in Conservation |
snippet.description:
In this module, you will learn about Most forest and wildlife resources are owned by the Government of India and managed through several departments like the Forest Department.
Forests are classified as Reserved Forests, Protected Forests and Unclassed Forests.
Over 50% of the forests in India have been declared reserved forests.
Jammu and Kashmir, Andhra Pradesh, Uttarakhand, Kerala, Tamil Nadu, West Bengal and Maharashtra have a large percentage of their forests classified as reserved forests.
Around one-third of the forests in India are classified as protected forests.
Most parts of the forests in Bihar, Haryana, Punjab, Himachal Pradesh, Orissa and Rajasthan are classified as protected forests.
Reserved and protected forests are together called permanent forests.
Madhya Pradesh has the largest share of permanent forests in India.
All the forests and wastelands, other than the reserved and protected forests, are considered unclassed forests.
Most of the forests in the north-eastern states of India and Gujarat are unclassed forests.
Religious faith has led to the conservation of certain specific types of trees in different parts of India.
Sacred groves are parts of forests or complete forests that are protected by communities since they are considered to be abodes of gods and goddesses. 
Several animals are also considered sacred, and, therefore, not harmed.
Forest-dwelling tribal communities are helping in conservation efforts to ensure their own survival.
Villagers cited the Wildlife Protection Act to fight against the ongoing mining activity inside the Sariska Tiger Reserve in Rajasthan. 
In Alwar district of Rajasthan, people from 5 villages have declared 1,200 hectares of forest as Bhairodev Dakav Sanctuary, with regulations against hunting and encroachments.
The Chipko Movement was started in 1970 in the Garhwal Himalayas of Uttarakhand, where people, including women and children, hugged trees to prevent them from being cut.
Farmers and citizen groups like Beej Bachao Andolan and Navdanya aim to conserve the environment by reviving traditional methods of organic farming.
Orissa launched the Joint Forest Management (JFM) program in 1988. 
Under JFM, local village communities participate in conservation efforts on degraded forest land in return for benefits of using the forest produce and a share in the timber harvested on the protected forest land.

snippet.title: CBSE Class 10 | Geography | Means of Communication |
snippet.description:
In this module, you will learn about Goods are transported from supply to demand locations by people called traders.
Transport is the key factor that influences India’s rapid economic development.
Based on the medium it uses, the means of transport can be divided into land transport, water transport and air transport.
Land transport includes roadways, railways and pipelines.
Water transport can be further classified as inland transport and overseas transport.
Air transport can be classified as domestic airways and international airways.
Modern advances in science and technology have not left any part of the world inaccessible.
Trade requires some means of exchanging ideas and connecting with people.
Means of communication allow people in different locations to connect with each other without actually travelling.
Some common means of communication are radio, television, cinema, newspapers, the Internet, fax and phone services.
Communication channels bring people from different cultural and social backgrounds together to make this world a global village.
A dense, efficient network of transport, and extensive, reliable means of communication are the true lifelines of trade and economic development for India and the rest of the world.

snippet.title: CBSE Class 10 | Geography | Means of Communication |
snippet.description:
In this module, you will learn about Goods are transported from supply to demand locations by people called traders.
Transport is the key factor that influences India’s rapid economic development.
Based on the medium it uses, the means of transport can be divided into land transport, water transport and air transport.
Land transport includes roadways, railways and pipelines.
Water transport can be further classified as inland transport and overseas transport.
Air transport can be classified as domestic airways and international airways.
Modern advances in science and technology have not left any part of the world inaccessible.
Trade requires some means of exchanging ideas and connecting with people.
Means of communication allow people in different locations to connect with each other without actually travelling.
Some common means of communication are radio, television, cinema, newspapers, the Internet, fax and phone services.
Communication channels bring people from different cultural and social backgrounds together to make this world a global village.
A dense, efficient network of transport, and extensive, reliable means of communication are the true lifelines of trade and economic development for India and the rest of the world.

snippet.title: CBSE Class 10 | Geography | Lifelines of Indian Economy Railways & Pipelines |
snippet.description:
In this module, you will learn about In India, railways are the primary mode of transport for passengers and goods.
The first train service in India began from Mumbai to Thane in 1853.
The development of railways has not only helped in uniting India, but also promoted the growth of agriculture and the economy.
The Indian railway network is spread over 63,221 route kilometres, connecting 7,031 railway stations all over the country divided into 16 railway zones.
The Indian railway network is serviced by 7,739 locomotives, 29,236 coaches and 2,16,717 wagons.
The distance between the two rails forming a railway track determines the gauge of the railway line.
Indian railways operate on narrow gauge, metre gauge and broad gauge lines.
The construction of railways depends largely on local terrain, and economic and administrative factors.
The vast level lands of the northern plains with the huge population and resources were the most favourable areas for the expansion of railways.
In the hilly peninsular region, railways lines were laid through hills, valleys and tunnels.
The Himalayan region with lesser population and economic opportunities are not favourable for the construction of railways.
The sandy deserts of Rajasthan, the swamps of Gujarat and the heavily forested regions of Madhya Pradesh, Orissa, Chhattisgarh and Jharkhand are some of the challenges railways have overcome for expansion in these regions.
Konkan Railway is prone to landslides and sinking of railway lines.
Considering the volume of passengers and goods transported, Indian Railways is more important to India’s economy than all other means of transport.
The challenges faced by Indian Railways include:
Without ticket travelling
Irresponsible chain pulling
Damage to railway property
Pipelines can be used to transport petroleum, natural gas and even coal slurry, from mining areas to industries and ports.
The three important gas and oil pipeline networks in India are:
Digboi to Kanpur oil pipeline via Guwahati, Barauni and Allahabad
Salaya to Jalandhar oil pipeline via Viramgam, Mathura, Delhi and Sonipat
Hazira to Jagdishpur gas pipeline via Vijaipur
Pipelines are:
Difficult and expensive to construct
Require very little maintenance
Eliminate transport losses and delays

snippet.title: CBSE Class 10 | Geography | Lifelines of Indian Economy Roadways |
snippet.description:
In this module, you will learn about roadways, The road network in India is amongst the largest in the world. 
The length of all the roads in India adds up to around 2.3 million kilometres.
The advantages that roadways have over railways are:
Easier, low-cost construction.
Ease of negotiating steep slopes and undulating land.
More cost-effective for lower volumes of transport over short distances.
Door-to-door connectivity.
Links other centres of transport like seaports, airports and railway stations.
Metalled roads are all-weather roads made of concrete, cement or coal tar.
Unmetalled roads go out of use in the rainy season.
Based on their capacity to sustain traffic, roads in India are classified as:
Golden Quadrilateral Super Highways
National Highways
State Highways
District Roads
Border Roads
Other Roads
The Golden Quadrilateral will be a six-lane super highway connecting Delhi, Mumbai, Chennai and Kolkata to each other.  
The East-West Corridor connects Silchar in Assam to Porbandar in Gujarat.
The North-South Corridor connects Srinagar in Jammu and Kashmir to Kanyakumari in Tamil Nadu.
National highways are constructed and maintained by the Central Public Works Department (CPWD).
In India, every national highway has been given a unique number.
Within a state, the roads linking the state capital with different district headquarters are called state highways.
State highways are constructed and maintained by the state’s Public Works Department or PWD.
The roads connecting a district headquarter to other destinations in the district are called district roads. 
District roads are constructed and maintained by the Zila Parishad.
The roads that run close to India’s international border in the north and north-eastern parts of the country are called border roads.
Border roads are constructed and maintained by the Border Roads Organisation (BRO).
Other roads are mostly rural roads that connect villages with nearby towns.
The Pradhan Mantri Grameen Sadak Yojna is a programme to connect each village to a town by a motorable road.
The length of roads per hundred square kilometres of area is called the road density.
Jammu and Kashmir has the lowest road density at 10 km, while Kerala has the highest at 375 km.
The average road density of Indian states is 75 km.
The challenges faced by roadways in India are:
Inadequate roads and highways
50% roads unmetalled and unusable in rains
Narrow roads and bridges in cities

snippet.title: CBSE Class 10 | Geography | Lifelines of Indian Economy Waterways & Airways |
snippet.description:
In this module, you will learn about Transport by waterways is the most fuel-efficient, cost-effective and environment-friendly way to carry heavy goods from one place to another. 
Around 95 percent of India’s international trade is carried out from its 12 major ports.
Air travel is the quickest and one of the most comfortable means of transport.
Nationalised air transport in India began in 1953.
Air travel is still very expensive in India and out of reach of a large part of the population.

snippet.title: CBSE Class 10 | Geography | Manufacturing Industries Agro Based Industries |
snippet.description:
In this module, you will learn about Agro Based Industries, Industries that use agricultural produce as raw material are called agro-based industries.
The Indian textile industry:
Contributes 14 percent of the total industrial production and 4 percent of the GDP.
Is the largest employer after the agriculture sector.
Generates 24.6 percent of India’s total foreign exchange earnings through exports.
Spinning, weaving, knitting, dyeing and finishing are important stages of production in the textile industry.
Cotton, woollen and silk are the main types of textiles produced in India.
India’s textile industry is completely self-reliant in terms of raw material and technology to produce finished garments from raw fibre.
At present, there are around 16,000 cotton textile mills in India.
The cotton textile industry supports people in a number of jobs, like farmers, cotton pickers, and workers engaged in ginning, spinning, weaving, dyeing, designing, packaging and tailoring.
In its modern form, the cotton textile industry started developing in India in the cotton growing regions of Maharashtra and Gujarat.
The cotton yarn spinning industry is still concentrated in Maharashtra, Gujarat and Tamil Nadu, while the weaving industry is spread over several parts of India.
India holds 25 percent share in the world market of cotton yarn, but only 4 percent in cotton garments.
Most industries in the weaving sector produce poor quality fabric for local markets.
India exports high-quality cotton yarn, but imports good quality cotton fabric.
The main challenges faced by the cotton textile industry in India are:
Need to import raw cotton to use the spinning capacity.
Unreliable supply of power.
Low output of labour.
Need to upgrade machinery.
Competition from the synthetic fibre industry.
India is the world’s largest producer of raw jute. 
India is the second largest exporter or raw jute and jute products in the world after Bangladesh. 
India has around 70 jute mills, most of which are located in West Bengal along the Hugli river. 
The main challenges faced by the jute industry in India are:
Competition from synthetic substitutes.
Competition from other jute manufacturing countries like Bangladesh, Brazil, Egypt, Philippines and Thailand.
The National Jute Policy was formulated in 2005 to:
Increase productivity 
Improve quality
Provide better rates for jute to farmers
Increase the yield of jute per hectare
Jute products are biodegradable and environment friendly. 
India is the largest producer of Gur and Khandsari, and the second largest producer of sugar in the world.
The sugar industry is a seasonal industry mainly run by cooperative societies.
Sugar mills must be located within or near the areas where sugarcane is cultivated.
India has 460 sugar mills, 60 percent of which are located in Uttar Pradesh and Bihar.
Over the past few years, the sugar industry appears to be shifting to the southern and western regions of India, especially Maharashtra.
The main challenges faced by the sugar industry in India are:
Its seasonal nature
Primitive inefficient methods of farming
Delays in transporting sugarcane to sugar mills
Need to find a use for the large amount of waste called bagasse

snippet.title: CBSE Class 10 | Geography | Fertiliser Cement Automobile & IT Industries |
snippet.description:
In this module, you will learn about The Indian fertiliser industry produces nitrogenous fertilisers like urea, phosphatic fertilisers like di-ammonium phosphate (DAP), and other complex fertilisers that are combinations of nitrogen, phosphate and potash.
India does not have any usable mineral reserves of potash, and imports all it requires. 
There are 57 fertiliser manufacturing units in India that produce several nitrogenous and complex fertilisers.
Gujarat, Tamil Nadu, Uttar Pradesh, Punjab and Kerala account for nearly 50 percent of the total fertiliser production in India.
Cement is an essential material for all kinds of construction.
In 1989, the government introduced several policy reforms like decontrol of cement pricing and distribution, which led to a rapid growth and expansion in the cement industry.
India has 128 large cement manufacturing plants and around 300 smaller plants. 
India exports cement to countries in East Asia, the Middle East, Africa and South Asia.
The cement industry uses heavy raw material like limestone, silica, alumina and gypsum in bulk quantities.
Most cement plants are located near limestone quarries.
The main cement-producing states in India are Gujarat, Rajasthan, Madhya Pradesh, Andhra Pradesh, Karnataka and Maharashtra.
India has a large automobile industry that produces passenger and goods transport vehicles.
The factors responsible for the growth in India of the automobile industry are:
Market liberalisation
Entry of new manufacturers and models
Increase in domestic and export demand
Foreign direct investment 
Introduction of latest technology
The main production centres of the Indian automobile industry are Delhi, Gurgaon, Mumbai, Chennai, Kolkata, Pune, Lucknow, Indore, Hyderabad, Bangalore and Jamshedpur.
There are 15 manufacturers of passenger cars and multi-utility vehicles, 9 manufacturers of commercial vehicles, and 14 manufacturers of two- and three-wheelers in India.
The electronics industry is engaged in manufacturing electronic gadgets and appliances.
The main production centres of the electronics industry are Bangalore, Delhi, Chennai, Pune, Mumbai, Hyderabad, Kolkata, Lucknow and Coimbatore.
The computer software and hardware industry, and the services enabled through computerisation, together form the information technology (IT) industry.
The Government of India has set up 18 software technology parks in different cities of India to provide all infrastructure and high data communication services to IT companies. 
The IT industry has generated a large number of employment opportunities.
Around 30 percent of IT employees are women.
The IT industry is also an important foreign exchange earner for India.

snippet.title: CBSE Class 10 | Geography | Industrial Pollution & Environmental Degradation |
snippet.description:
In this module, you will learn about Industrial Pollution & Environmental Degradation, Industrialisation has caused severe pollution of our natural resources.
Industries cause environmental degradation through:
Air pollution
Water pollution
Land pollution or soil degradation
Noise pollution
Smoke contains undesirable gases like carbon dioxide, sulphur dioxide and carbon monoxide, besides solid and liquid particulate matter in the form of dust and spray mist that cause air pollution.
Air pollution affects the health of humans, animals and plants alike, and also causes damage to buildings.
Water pollution is caused by the discharge of untreated chemical waste, heavy metals like lead and mercury, pesticides, fertilisers and plastics from industries, into fresh water bodies like rivers and lakes.
Solid wastes like fly ash, phospo-gypsum, iron and steel slag also cause water pollution.
The industries that cause major amount of water pollution are paper and pulp industries, oil refineries, tanneries, and electroplating industries.
The discharge of hot water from thermal power plants into rivers before cooling is called thermal pollution of water.
Radioactive waste, hazardous chemicals, glass, plastic, industrial effluents and non-biodegradable garbage are the main agents of land pollution.
Rain water falling on polluted land dissolves and carries many pollutants further into the ground and pollutes groundwater.
Industrial machinery, construction activities, generators, and equipment like saws and pneumatic drills, are mainly responsible for noise pollution. 
Loud noise can lead to irritation, loss of hearing, and an increase in the blood pressure and heart rate.
Polluted wastewater from industries must be treated before releasing it into water bodies.
Wastewater treatment involves:
Primary treatment through screening, grinding, flocculation and sedimentation
Secondary treatment through bacterial action to digest harmful chemicals
Tertiary stage of stirring with chemicals to neutralise remaining harmful waste
Treated wastewater can be recycled for reuse in industrial processes.
Rainwater harvesting can be used to meet the requirements of water for industrial processes.
Legal provisions must be made to regulate the use of groundwater for industrial use.
Smoke stacks, filters, scrubbers, and electrostatic and inertial separators remove a large amount of harmful particles from industrial smoke.
The emission of smoke from industries can be reduced by using more efficient fuels like oil and natural gas in place of coal.
Industrial and generator silencers, and sound-absorbing material should be used to reduce the noise level in industries.
Industrial workers can use earphones and earplugs for individual protection of health and hearing.
National Thermal Power Corporation (NTPC) is a major electricity generating and distribution company in India.
NTPC has demonstrated how conservation of environment and natural resources can happen simultaneously with industrial growth by:
Adopting latest technical knowhow
Minimising waste
Providing green cover
Reducing environmental pollution
Continuous monitoring

snippet.title: CBSE Class 10 | Geography | Manufacturing Industries Introduction |
snippet.description:
In this module, you will learn about Manufacturing Industries Introduction, The process of using raw material to produce more valuable goods in large quantities is called manufacturing.
Industries that manufacture finished products from primary materials are called manufacturing industries in the secondary sector.
Manufacturing industries play a crucial role in the overall and especially economic development of a country.
A country’s economic strength is measured by the growth of its manufacturing industries.
The growth in manufacturing industries has:
Modernised farming.
Generated employment opportunities and reduced the dependence of people on agriculture.
Allowed us to export goods to other countries and build up our reserves of foreign exchange.
Led to overall growth and prosperity.
Agriculture and industry mutually benefit each other.
India has a large number of agro-based industries that depend on agricultural produce for raw material.
Agriculture plays an important role in expanding our manufacturing industry.
Manufacturing industry provides farmers with fertilisers, pesticides, and different types of farming machines and equipment.
To stay competitive in the global market, we must ensure that the quality of our goods is at par with the best.

snippet.title: CBSE Class 10 | Geography | Location & Classification of Industries |
snippet.description:
In this module, you will learn about Location & Classification of Industries, The key factor influencing all decisions about setting up a manufacturing industry, including its location, is the cost.
The ideal location for a factory is a place that has easy and low-cost availability of raw material, capital, land, labour, power, transport, and market.
A manufacturing industry promotes the urbanisation of its neighbourhood.
Already urbanised areas attract industries, since they provide ready facilities for transport, banking, labour, consultancy, etc.
Several industries come up together at an urban centre to form an industrial agglomeration.
Before independence, most industries in India were located in port cities to enable easy overseas trade.
Manufacturing industries can be classified based on basis of their source of raw material, role, capital investment, ownership pattern, and bulk of supplies like raw material and finished products.
Based on their source of raw material, manufacturing industries can be classified as agro-based industries and mineral-based industries.
Based on the weight or bulk of raw material used and finished products, manufacturing industries can be classified as heavy and light industries.
Based on their role, manufacturing industries can be classified as basic or key industries, and consumer industries.
Based on the capital investment, manufacturing industries can be classified as small-scale and large-scale industries.
Based on the pattern of ownership, manufacturing industries can be classified as public sector, private sector, joint sector and cooperative industries.
Manufacturing industries contribute only 17 percent to our GDP.
The National Manufacturing Competitiveness Council (NMCC) has been set up to achieve a growth of 12% in the manufacturing industry by adopting appropriate policies and improving productivity.
